criteria: Understanding of the Sum of Rational and Irrational Numbers
Understanding of the Product of Rational and Irrational Numbers
descriptions: Student demonstrates no understanding of rational numbers.
Student can identify rational numbers but cannot explain their properties.
Student can define rational numbers and give examples but struggles to explain why the sum/product of two rational numbers is rational.
Student can explain why the sum of two rational numbers is rational but struggles with the product.
Student can explain why the sum and product of two rational numbers are rational with minor errors.
Student clearly and accurately explains why the sum and product of two rational numbers are rational, providing thorough justification.
Student demonstrates no understanding of irrational numbers or their relationship with rational numbers.
Student can identify irrational numbers but not explain the result of summing a rational and irrational number.
Student attempts to explain the sum of a rational and irrational number, but explanation is unclear or incorrect.
Student generally explains the sum of rational and irrational numbers but lacks precision or full understanding.
Student accurately explains why the sum of a rational and an irrational number is irrational with a good explanation.
Student clearly and thoroughly explains why the sum of a rational and an irrational number is irrational, providing clear and logical reasoning.
Student demonstrates no understanding of how multiplying rational and irrational numbers results in an irrational number.
Student can state that the product of a rational and irrational number is irrational but cannot explain why.
Student attempts to explain the product of rational and irrational numbers, but explanation contains significant errors or gaps.
Student generally explains the product of rational and irrational numbers but does not address the condition of a 'nonzero' rational number.
Student accurately explains why the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational but lacks clarity.
Student clearly, accurately, and thoroughly explains why the product of a nonzero rational number and an irrational number is irrational, including the importance of the 'nonzero' condition.
